This exercise requires us to describe the effect JIT is likely to have on the 
companyâ€™s carrying costs, shortage costs, and operating cycle.

**Just-in-time (JIT) Inventory System** is inventory strategy that manufacturers used to increase their efficiency. These include ordering and receiving inventories for production as well as client sales only as needed to make goods. 

JIT inventory **minimizes** the carrying costs and operating cycle of the company. The shortage costs in this inventory system will increase based on how accurately the company estimates their demands.
In this question, we are asked to relate the effect on the carrying costs, shortage costs, and operating cycle of the company

**Just in time inventory** is an approach to inventory management that calls for maintaining tight relationships with one's suppliers in order to ensure that raw materials arrive exactly when manufacturing is planned to start and not a moment before. The objective is to satisfy customer demand with the fewest possible items in stock at any one time.

The corporate records only such quantity of supply requisite. As a direct consequence, variable expenses will drop. If indeed the manufacturing process has become too unbalanced or unforeseen, stockpile supply disruptions might very well occur, resulting in manufacturing problems and steadily increasing incidental expenses.

The operating cycle seems to be the amount of time required for an investor to produce stock levels, repurpose them into goods and services, distribute them as well, and obtain their receivables and payables. Running cycle = Days Stockpile + Days Current Liabilities is the typical method. So, there's less stockpile, the duration necessary to turn collection in and out of refined products is reduced, and there's a shorter overall operating period.
